awd_titl_txt: A Fundamental Study on Gas Film Formation and its Effect in Electrochemical Discharge Machining Process
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced engineering materials and alloys possess excellent physical properties. However, machining these materials by traditional methods is difficult due to their hardness, brittleness, and other characteristics, leading to increased tool wear and surface damage. This award supports a fundamental study of electrochemical discharge machining (ECDM) - a nontraditional process that improves the surface integrity of advanced engineering materials that are critical for the US economy and national security. Using modeling, simulation and experimental methods, the formation and stability of gas film in the ECDM of advanced materials will be studied. The topography, mechanical and tribological properties, and composition of the machined surface will be analyzed subsequently. The expected improvement in the machinability of a wide variety of both conductive and nonconductive materials will help in unleashing the full application potential of these materials in biomedical, electronic, automotive, and energy industries. Potential applications in these industries include hip joint prosthesis, electronics packaging, brake linings, and solid oxide fuel cells. The multi-disciplinary approach and results of this study can be extended to other electrical machining processes. The outcome of this project will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses, and training and learning within female and underrepresented minorities. The results of this research will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at professional society meetings, and YouTube videos.

Through this research, fundamental knowledge on the mechanism of gas film formation and stability during the electrochemical discharge machining process will be generated by conducting analytical and experimental investigations to understand the effect of thickness and stability of the gas film on the surface integrity changes in machined parts. Critical insight into the rate of gas bubble formation, the rate of coalescence, and the gas film thickness will be acquired by molecular dynamics simulations to produce stable and thin gas film. Finite element simulations coupling electrical, chemical and thermal aspects of ECDM will be pursued to investigate the hydrodynamic behavior of boundary layers during gas film formation. Multi-physics based mathematical models will be developed to predict the gas film thickness, discharge energy and surface roughness in ECDM. Sensor fusion of optical and electrical feedback signals will be used in the experimental studies for in-process monitoring and control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The major goal of this project is to improve the surface integrity of machined features in the electrochemical discharge machining (ECDM) process. The research activities conducted in this project has helped advance ECDM, an emerging nontraditional material removal process capable of electrothermal machining of any material irrespective of its conductivity. Outcomes of this project include: demonstration of an in-house-built setup to perform ECDM, and a control system to perform ECDM in noncontact mode. Additionally, a computational framework  to simulate ECDM at continuum and atomic scale has been developed.

A physics based mathematical model was developed to predict the minimum gas film thickness. A thinner gas film layer minimizes overcut and surface damage. Surface integrity was improved when pulse current with lower duty cycle was used. Incorporating sodium or potassium ions into acidic electrolyte was found to mitigate both chemical and thermal damages. The results, shown in Figure 1 (d), demonstrate a significant reduction in both chemical and thermal damage compared to the results obtained with a single electrolyte.

Figure 1. Illustration of the major result in mixing electrolyte to improve the surface integrity. 

A multiphase finite element simulation to investigate the impact of gas film characteristics on overcut in electrochemical discharge machining revealed that gas film thickness and stability were influenced by electrolyte level and affected overcut. A molecular dynamics simulation revealed the relationship between the applied voltage and gas film density which plays a crucial role in determining the critical voltage in ECDM.

BROADER IMPACT 

The research outcomes include a new setup to perform electrochemical discharge machining in contact and noncontact modes. In the process of developing the setup in-house, students were exposed to educational opportunities by touring the lab and working in the lab. Every academic semester, one or two class cohorts visited the lab and had a chance to see the research in process presented by graduate and undergraduate students working in the lab; questions and dialogue were encouraged. Several students worked in the lab every semester and were exposed to working with facets of research and development of the processes, including: building of physical setups, coding control systems, conducting experiments, improving the process performance, and helping code features of the molecular dynamics simulation. Various facets of the work were delegated to students; independent, creative thinking and problem solving were encouraged. One student even developed a control system to ensure ECDM in complete noncontact mode. Freshmen students also had the chance to work in the lab as part of the prestigious prot?g? program and present theirnfindings at the UC Undergraduate Scholarly Research Showcase.

This award also assisted with advancing the participation of minorities in advanced manufacturing. Two female graduate students on the MS track, and several undergraduate students have made contributions in lab activities over the last several semesters. Working in the lab via this project has exposed these students to be involved in advanced manufacturing research in a way that they may otherwise have not been easily exposed to. Tours and presentations were given to school-children via the Cincinnati Enhanced Engineering Math and Science (CEEMS) program; and an outreach event at UC via the Greater Cincinnati STEM collaborative.

The project has resulted in 1 doctoral dissertation (nearing completion), 3 MS theses (2 completed, 1 nearing completion), 10 refereed publications (7 completed, 3 in preparation). The products in progress are expected to be finalized by December 2023.

 


Last Modified: 07/27/2023
Modified by: Murali Sundaram
